page.title: 05WILD FLOWERS AND TREES
page.content: The flora varies according to height, terrain and land use. Flowers and grasses in the hay meadows, some of which have been cut for hundreds of years, are abundant. In the pastures they are not so for the obvious reason that they have difficulty establishing themselves. On the rocks of the scars, the plants are small and delicate. The area is rich in a large number of uncommon species. The predominant tree of the area, flourishing in the limey soil, is the ash. From the present tree cover, it would not be easily recognised that this area was once part of the great deciduous forest of Wensleydale. The trees now come under the protection of the{Yorkshire Dales {National Park.
